title.rendered: AWS vs Azure vs Google Cloud: Which Platform Is Best?

content.rendered:
Choosing the right platform becomes paramount in the dynamic realm of cloud computing, where demand is skyrocketing. That’s why AWS Google Cloud plays an important role.

AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud dominate the market, offering data storage, network access, and more. Before delving into the AWS vs. Azure vs. Google Cloud debate, let’s glance at some intriguing stats.

Did you know?

  • 40% of enterprises allocate $1.2 million to AWS.
  • Azure commands a 36% share with the same $1.2 million spending.
  • Google Cloud, while growing, sees 18% of enterprises investing the same amount.

The burning question: Which one reigns supreme?  Which is better Azure or AWS?

In this blog, we navigate through the intricacies of these cloud giants, i.e., Azure AWS Google comparison, dissecting various parameters to unveil the best cloud computing platform among AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud.

Embark on this journey with us as we demystify the Azure vs Google Cloud vs AWS debate. Whether you’re steering a startup or an enterprise’s cloud strategy, clarity awaits as we chart the course through the cloud computing landscape.

AWS Vs Azure Vs Google Cloud Comparison: Overview

The details related to AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud will help you in analyzing the result of the AWS vs Azure vs Google war.

Amazon Web Services (AWS)

AWS cloud services are reliable, and it includes compute power, database storage, content delivery, and other functionalities to help businesses scale and grow. It is the world’s most comprehensive and broadly embraced cloud platform, conceding over 175 fully-featured services globally.

Pros

  • Ease of Use
  • Incredibly Diverse Array of Tools
  • Unlimited Server Capacity
  • Amazon’s EC2 Limits

Cons

  • Limitations OF Amazon EC2
  • Security Limitations

Microsoft Azure

Microsoft Azure cloud computing platform provides multiple solutions including, Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS) that can be utilized for analytics, virtual computing, storage, networking, and much more.

Microsoft Azure Cloud Services are trustworthy; you can choose this platform for gaining multiple profits.

Pros

  • Data Security
  • Cost-Effective
  • App-friendly
  • Scalable

Cons

  • Requires Management
  • Requires Platform Expertise
  • Difficult Migration

Also read: Google Cloud VS Azure: Which Platform Is Best To Pick ?

Google Cloud Platform

Google Cloud Platform includes multiple features like networking, big data, storage, internet of things (IoT), cloud management, machine learning, and much more.

It runs on similar Infrastructure that Google utilizes internally for its end-user products like YouTube, Google Search Engine, and more.

Google cloud services taken from a reliable software outsourcing company offer numerous functionalities, and that’s why it attracts multiple users.

Pros

  • G-Suite
  • Insights from AI
  • Highly Secure

Cons

  • Poor documentation
  • Need Management

Comparison of AWS Google Cloud and Azure

Now, the question arise, which is best Azure or AWS or Google Cloud?

The GCP vs AWS vs Azure cloud platforms comparison has been done using various parameters of the Cloud Computing platform. Let’s quickly check below:

AWS vs Azure vs Google Cloud: Accessibility Zones

AWS offers hosting in multiple locations globally, like Azure, and Google Cloud also does the same thing. The difference occurs in the number only. From below, view the numbers of Availability Zones of AWS, Azure, and GPS.

  • AWS has 66 availability zones, with 12 more on the way.
  • Azure has 54 regions globally, open to 140 countries.
  • Google Cloud Platform (GCP) is accessible in 20 regions globally, with 3 more on their way.

AWS vs Google Cloud vs Azure: Market Shares

Take a quick look at the market shares to find which is best AWS or Azure or Google cloud?

If we talk about the cloud market, then AWS is on the first level. To be more clear, view the image mentioned below.

  • AWS is leading with around 32% of the market share.
  • Microsoft Azure is in second place, owning around 22% market share.
  • Google Cloud, in the third place, owns up to 11% market share.

Also Read: Multi Cloud vs Hybrid Cloud: Know the Difference Between Two Cloud Platforms

Azure vs AWS vs Google: Public Cloud Adoption for Enterprises

In the public cloud adoption rate, Azure is at the leading position; AWS and Google Cloud are at the second and third positions, respectively.

Therefore, you have advantages of Azure over AWS for your enterprises; this will help gain multiple benefits like data storage, computing, networking, and more.

  • 76% of enterprise respondents are currently using AWS.
  • 69% of enterprise respondents are currently using Azure.
  • 34% of enterprise respondents are currently using Google.

Amazon Web Services vs Google Cloud vs Azure: Services

These three cloud platforms are forming well in the market. The services of these platforms are offering top-level solutions.

  • AWS offers more than 200 services.
  • Azure offers more than 200 services.
  • Google Cloud offers more than 160 services.

Services offered by AWS, Azure, and GCP come under computing, database, storage, and networking domains. Have a look at the cloud platforms’ various domains offering and analyze the outcome of AWS vs Google Cloud vs Azure.

Also read: Top Cloud Computing Trends That Will Shape Businesses In The Coming Years

AWS vs Azure vs Google Cloud Provider Comparison: Pricing

AWS Pricing

Smallest Instance: A basic instance includes 2 virtual CPUs and 8 GB of RAM. Its cost is around US$69 per month.

Largest Instance: AWS’s largest instance includes 3.84 TB of RAM and 128 vCPUs. It costs around US$3.97/hour.

Azure Pricing

Smallest Instance: Azure small instance includes 2 vCPUs and 8 GB of RAM. Its cost is around US$70/month.

Largest Instance: The Azure largest instance includes 3.89 TB of RAM and 128 vCPUs. Its pricing is around US$6.79/hour.

Google Cloud

Small Instance: In Comparison with AWS and Azure, GCP provides the most basic instance, including 2 virtual CPUs and 8 GB of RAM at a 25% cheaper rate. So, it’s cost will be around US$52/month.

Largest Instance: GCP’s largest instance includes 3.75 TB of RAM and 160 vCPUs. It will cost around US$5.32/hour.

Important Note: AWS started offering pay-per-minute billing. Azure previously offers pay-per-minute billing, while Google Cloud Platform (GCP) offers pay-per-second billing models that benefit users in saving money more than AWS or Azure.

Google offers various discounts to the customers, which helps them save up to 50% in some cases when compared to AWS vs Azure for startups. Gartner stated Google offers wide discounts and especially flexible deals to win projects from clients.

AWS vs Azure vs Google Cloud: Famous Brands Using Them

AWS is one of the experienced players in the cloud market; it has wide community support and a user base.

Multiple famous brands, like Netflix, Airbnb, Unilever, BMW, Samsung, MI, Zynga, Twitch, LinkedIn, Facebook, Baidu, ESPN, and more use AWS globally.

Moreover, using AWS technology, invertio experts also developed several applications such as Church App, Online Food Ordering Hub, and more.

Azure has high-profile customers with time and has almost 80% of Fortune 500 companies as its clients.

Some famous brands which are using Azure are eBay, Boeing, Samsung, HP, Polycom GE Healthcare, Johnson Controls, BMW, Travelocity, Fujifilm, Honeywell, Apple, etc.

Google is itself a leading brand; it has a large value in the market, and that’s why Google Cloud and Google app engine services are availed by multiple brands.

The famous clients using Google Cloud are HSBC, Vimeo, Twitter, PayPal, Snapchat, 20th Century Fox, BestBuy, Bloomberg, Dominos, Spotify, and more.

Also read: Top 20 Cloud Services Companies For Enterprises To Connect With

Wrapping Up

After an exhaustive analysis of AWS vs Azure vs Google Cloud, AWS emerges as the current frontrunner, outscoring Azure and Google Cloud.

Yet, the future remains unpredictable, as both Azure and Google Cloud offer robust functionalities, hinting at a potential shift in the cloud dominance landscape.
